answers: eddas [or eddur; accept Poetic Edda; accept Prose Edda; accept Elder Edda; accept Younger Edda]
parts: Name this realm of the Norse gods. It is connected to Midgard by the Bifrost rainbow bridge.
The "poetic" one of these works retells the Aesir-Vanir war. Snorri Sturluson wrote the "Prose" one of these Icelandic works, our main primary sources for Norse myth.
This omniscient man was created as a symbol of truce during the war when all the gods spit into a cauldron. The blood of this murder victim was used to make the Mead of Poetry.

answers: flowers [or the Flower Vendor; or lilies]
parts: Name this woman, who also painted two versions of herself with exposed hearts that are connected by a cord. At age 18, her spine was broken when the bus she was riding in collided with a trolley.
Frida Kahlo was the wife of this other Mexican painter and muralist, whose own works include Detroit Industry and Man at the Crossroads.

A popular Diego Rivera painting shows an Indian girl, with her back to the viewer and her feet impossibly contorted, extending her arms to encompass a bunch of these objects. Dutch painter Rachel Ruysch specialized in painting these objects.

answers: First Bull Run [or First Manassas; prompt on "Bull Run"; prompt on "Manassas"]
parts: Pioneers using this technology included J.F. Pilatre de Rozier and the Marquis d'Arlandes, although the most famous early practitioners are probably the Montgolfier brothers.

This man, then serving as the American ambassador, gave a first hand account of some of the early balloon experiments in France. His own inventions include bifocals, the lightning rod and a namesake stove.

Thadeus Lowe's reconnaissance balloon Enterprise played a significant role in this Civil War battle. The Pennsylvania Reserves were activated after this battle, whose victors failed to pursue the enemy due to a squabble between Bonham and Longstreet.
Name these two sets of eight pieces for piano four-hands. The first set of these opens with a furiant in C Major.
The Slavonic Dances were composed by this Czech composer also known for his "New World" Symphony.
Dvorak also composed one of these works nicknamed "Dumky" for its use of that ballad form. Beethoven composed one of these works nicknamed "Archduke".

answers: Desdichado [or the Disinherited One/Knight; or Unfortunate]
Robin of Locksley [accept either underlined portion; accept Robin Hood]
parts: Name this Walter Scott novel whose title Saxon knight defeats Brian Bois-Guilbert to save Rebecca from being burned for being a witch.
This is the name Ivanhoe adopts during the tournament where he defeats The Black Knight.

In another scene from Ivanhoe, this green-clad character wins an archery contest by perfectly splitting Hubert's arrow with his own arrow. He leads a band of outlaws including the Friar of Copmanhurst.

answers: Golda Meir [or Goldie Mabovitch or Goldie Myerson]
The 1973 Arab-Israeli War [or the Yom Kippur War; or the October War; or the Ramadan War; or the Fourth Arab-Israeli War]
parts: Identify this one-time Milwaukee resident who served between Levi Eshkol and Yitzhak Rabin as the 4th Prime Minister of Israel in 1969.
Golda Meir was criticized for not being prepared for this conflict, often named for a Jewish holiday. The first oil embargo was launched due to US aid to Israel in this war.
In the earlier Six Day War, fifteen ships stranded in the Suez Canal became known as the fleet of this color. The legendary ruler Huangdi is often identified with this color.

answers: Joseph Conrad [or Jozef Teodor Konrad Korzeniowski]
Ford Madox Ford [accept Ford Madox Hueffer or Ford Hermann Hueffer]
parts: Name this ivory trader whose report to the International Society for the Suppression of Savage Customs ends with an exhortation to "exterminate all the brutes!" and is discovered by Marlow.
This Polish-British author of Heart of Darkness commented on the decline of colonialism in his short story "An Outpost of Progress".
Conrad collaborated on three works -- The Inheritors, Romance, and The Nature of a Crime -- with this English author of the Parade's End tetralogy.
Name this protein which is found in hair and nails. Mutations in the 5 and 14 varieties of this protein cause epidermolysis bullosa simplex.
Keratin bundles form these components of the cytoskeleton. Vimentin, desmin, and GFAP can also form these filaments, which are larger than actin but smaller than microtubules.
These are the intermediate filaments found on the inner surface the nucleus. They are phosphorylated and disassemble during mitosis and they are mutated in Hutchinson-Gilford progeria.
Name this country, where the Assembly of First Nations joined the Liberals and the NDP in calling for Stephen Harper's government to respect Aboriginal treaty rights.

Spence's hunger strike has inspired this Aboriginal protest movement, which has called for Canada's Governor General to participate in negotiations as the representative of the Crown, the traditional guarantor of Aboriginals' ignored rights.
One of the most vocal backers of Idle No More has been this former Liberal prime minister, whom Harper defeated and replaced in Canada's 2006 general election.

answers: attenuation [do not accept or prompt on "absorption"]
parts: These particles, equivalent to a helium nucleus, consist of two protons and two neutrons. They are particularly dangerous when ingested, since they are typically blocked by skin.
Radiation detectors frequently contain one of these transparent materials, which absorb radiation and emit a larger amount of light, which can be detected by a PMT.
Materials that are good shields of radiation typically have high values of this process' namesake coefficient. More generally, it refers to a reduction in the flux intensity in a medium.
Name this 24-story, blue-green box-shaped skyscraper in New York. It was designed by Gordon Bunshaft and is located at 390 Park Avenue.

The Lever House sits across from this other building, whose architect, Mies van der Rohe, used non-structural bronze-toned I-beams to suggest its structure and mandated that the blinds have only three fixed positions.
The Seagram Building was designed by Mies van der Rohe with help from this other architect of the Crystal Cathedral and the Glass House.

answers: azimuthal quantum number [or angular momentum quantum number]
parts: Name these numbers which represent the state of electrons in atoms. Electrons in atoms are usually described with four of them.
This quantum number symbolized l represents the shape of an orbital in which an electron is found. It equals one for p orbitals.

According to one of these rules governing electronic transitions, a transition is allowed only if the change in azimuthal quantum number equals plus or minus one. According to one of these statements named for Laporte, transitions where parity is conserved are forbidden.

answers: anti-Tom novels/literature/etc. [or plantation novels/literature/etc.; accept explanatory equivalents like "responses to Uncle Tom's Cabin" or "works written in opposition to Uncle Tom's Cabin"; prompt on "pro-slavery literature" or equivalents that don't mention "Tom" or Uncle Tom's Cabin]
parts: Identify this nineteenth-century literary genre, also exemplified by William Gilmore Simms's The Sword and the Distaff. Novels in this genre were characterized by their desire to rebut another author's 1852 bestseller.
Anti-Tom novels were, as the name might suggest, the product of pro-slavery Southern writers' outraged reaction to this author's novel Uncle Tom's Cabin.

This villainous fiend from Uncle Tom's Cabin, possibly based on a man from Louisiana named Meredith Calhoun, owns a plantation and takes Cassy as his mistress. At the end of the novel, he orders his overseers to murder Tom.

answers: Jesuits [or Society of Jesus or Societas Iesu]
House of Savoy [or Casa di Savoia]
Francis I [or Francois I; prompt on Francis; prompt on Francois]
parts: Clement XIV abolished this religious order in 1773. This order was founded by Ignatius of Loyola and was a key force in the Counter-Reformation.

Clement XI got into a conflict with Victor Amadeus II of this royal family over control of Sicily. Founded by Umberto the White-Handed in the 11th century, this family would later rule over all of Italy beginning with Victor Emmanuel II.
Clement VII was a staunch ally of this Valois French king, who defeated Clement's cousin Leo X and his Swiss allies at the Battle of Marignano.

answers: Critique of Pure Reason [or Kritik der reinen Vernunft]
necessary truths [or necessities; accept word forms]
parts: Name this type of truth designated by a Latin term, which can be learned or derived without any empirical experience.
This Kant treatise asked whether synthetic a priori truths are possible. The first in a series of three, it tried to show when human deduction oversteps its bounds.

Saul Kripke studied this other set of truths, which must be true in all possible worlds or conceivable situations. They might not all be knowable a priori and make up the second subject of his most famous Princeton lecture series.

answers: Eichmann in Jerusalem: a Report on the Banality of Evil
parts: Name this 1963 book that used the phrase "banality of evil" to describe the title man's lack of violent motivation for his political and war crimes.
This German-American thinker wrote about the Nazis' megalomania in Origins of Totalitarianism several years before writing Eichmann in Jerusalem.

Since the Nazis were so power-hungry, Arendt considered Jewish identity to be incidental to the existence of this event. This massacre led to the deaths of over six million Jews between 1939 and 1945 in places like Auschwitz and Treblinka.

Expressions in predicate logic are comprised of sentence symbols and logical symbols. One such logical symbol is this one, which is only true if both of the inputs are true. It is commonly distinguished from OR.

Some expressions do not make sense in predicate logic, such as "p ^^ q" [read as: "p and and q"]. Such statements lack this property, which is the equivalent of being syntactically correct for a logical system.
In logic, binding a variable over a universe of discourse is done using these operators. They include the existential one and the universal one.

answers: The Good Soldier Svejk [or Osudy Dobreho Vojaka Svejka ve Svetove Valky; or The Fateful Adventures of the Good Soldier Svejk During the World War]
parts: Identify this Jaroslav Hasek novel about the feebleminded Josef, a dealer in stolen dogs who at one point serves as an altar boy for the chaplain, Otto Katz.

This writer, who like Hasek wrote in Czech, depicted Captain van Toch's discovery of an intelligent race of lizards on an island near Sumatra in his novel War with the Newts and penned a play whose protagonist is Helena Glory.
That Capek play, R.U.R., contains the first appearance of this word, used to indicate the artificial people constructed in Harry Domin's factory. It was coined by Capek's brother Josef.

answers: the sacred mirror [or Yata no Kagami]
parts: Name this national religion of Japan, which reveres gods and spirits of nature called kami.
Shinto shrines are delineated by wooden examples of these structures with two crossbars, called torii. These objects "of Prayer" name the most common prayer book in Reform Judaism.
This object, one of Japan's three imperial regalia, is allegedly housed in the Ise Shrine, a holy site in Shinto. This object was used to help lure the sun goddess Amaterasu out of a cave

answers: Haka [or Hakka, which will sound the same]
parts: Identify this site of the Taranaki and Musket wars, ruled by colonial governor George Grey by the terms of an 1840 treaty.
New Zealand is home to these Polynesian people, whose leaders have included Te Wherowhero.

The peruperu form of this ritualistic Maori dance was performed before setting out for war. A close homophone of this term identifies a southern Chinese ethnic group that formed the initial core of the Taiping Rebellion.

answers: toxoplasmosis [accept Toxoplasma gondii or T gondii]
parts: Name this lentivirus which causes AIDS
AIDS is tracked by counting the number of T cells expressing this surface molecule. Along with CD3, this molecule is expressed by helper T-cells.
This AIDS-defining illness is caused by a protozoan carried by cats. It can cause both encephalitis and chorioretinitis and can also cross the placenta.

answers: Stone of Scone [or Stone of Destiny or Lia Fail]
parts: Identify this family whose final prominent member, Edward, was a claimant to the throne of Scotland held by the House of Bruce.
Scotland was invaded in 1296 by an English king of this name, nicknamed Longshanks. This name was also borne by an English king known as "the Confessor."
Edward I removed this object and brought it to England, where it was placed under the coronation chair. This rock was traditionally used to crown Scottish monarchs.
This Shirley Jackson short story depicts a small New England village gathering for a ritual that ends with Tess Hutchinson's death in a human sacrifice by stoning.

Suburban customs were parodied in many of this author's stories, including the grim story "The Swimmer," which ends with the mental breakdown of protagonist Neddy Merrill. He also wrote The Wapshot Chronicle.

This man wrote numerous New Yorker stories, but is better remembered now for his novels, examples of which include his book about a presidential candidate called Ten North Frederick and his novel about Gloria Wandrous, BUtterfield 8.
